qas.question: What is another term for procedural memory?
If bob remembered how to bake a cake after seeing this on television what memory is he using?
What set of skills is reliant on procedural memory?
If Bob does throws 15 more free throws than he did last week, how many more explicit memories has he gained?

answers.text: no new explicit memories have been formed,

qas.question: What is another term for procedural senses?
If bob remembered how to bake a cake after seeing this on television what sense is he using?
What set of skills is not reliant on procedural memory?
What type of memory does not depend on the cerebellum and basal ganglia?
What type of memory is secondarily employed in learning motor skills and should be considered a subset of implicit memory

context: In contrast, <a1_0><b5_0>procedural memory<b5_0/><a1_0/> (or <a0_0><b4_0>implicit memory<b4_0/><a0_0/>) is not based on the conscious recall of information, but on implicit learning. It can best be summarized as remember how to do something. <b8_0>Procedural memory<b8_0/> is primarily employed in learning <a2_0><b6_0>motor skills<b6_0/><a2_0/> and should be considered a subset of implicit memory. It is revealed when one does better in a given task due only to repetition - <a3_0>no new explicit memories have been formed,<a3_0/> but one is unconsciously accessing aspects of those previous experiences. <b7_0>Procedural memory<b7_0/> involved in motor learning depends on the cerebellum and basal ganglia.
